comment._content: George Arthur Crump (1871-1918), designed golf courses: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Arthur_Crump

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Dunno if that's the same guy, though. Here's a picture of the golfer Crump: kellysgolfhistory.blogspot.com/2009/04/george-crump.html

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: books.google.com/books?id=sQ8LAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA430&l... refers to a George Crump, Jr. who was pardoned in 1914 for a conviction for forgery.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Ooh.... that sounds like a more interesting story than the golf course guy.  ;)  And the Jr. part makes it more likely to me that this might be the pardoned forger.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Doesn't matter any more.  This picture has been posted on Wikipedia, so he's going to have to be a golfer forever....

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Nah, the beauty of Wikipedia is that anything that's posted can get unposted. Let's figure this out and set it straight. It still might be the golfer. In February 1914 the Pine Valley golf course that Crump designed opened for play. George A. Crump had sold his hotel in Philadelphia to help finance its construction. So his timeline fits the Bain collection too. But I'd agree that this doesn't look like the same guy: golfclubatlas.com/in-my-opinion/thomas-macwood-george-art... And of course, it's not impossible this is some other guy entirely--there have been a few photographs here that were completely mislabeled in their original captions.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content:
The guy in your link doesn't look like the same guy in the Bain photo, but he looks like the guy in the link I posted.    Maybe this is the golfer's wayward son... 

(And I knew Wikipedia can be fixed -- I forgot to add the ":)" . )   :)
